document.masterDocTitle: The genus Arachnomimus Saussure, 1897 (Orthoptera: Phalangopsidae) in India with description of a new subgenus and species from a cave in Chhattisgarh India

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: The genus Arachnomimus Saussure, 1897 (Orthoptera: Phalangopsidae) in India with description of a new subgenus and species from a cave in Chhattisgarh India

mods:name.mods:affiliation: Department of Zoology, Panjab University, Chandigarh, 160014, India https: // orcid. org / 0000 - 0001 - 6276 - 8785

Institut de Systématique, Evolution, Biodiversité (ISYEB), Muséum national d’Histoire naturelle, CNRS, Sorbonne Université, EPHE, Université des Antilles 57 rue Cuvier, CP 50, 75231 Paris Cedex 05, France & https: // orcid. org / 0000 - 0002 - 7781 - 3451

bibRefCitation.author: Saussure, H. de
bibRefCitation.refString: Saussure, H. de. (1878) Melanges orthopterologiques. VIeme fascicule. Gryllides (2 eme partie). Memoires de la Societe de Physique et d'Histoire naturelle de Geneve, 25, 369 - 702.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Included species. In addition to
Arachnomimus jayanti
Jaiswara,
sp. nov.
described here, 11 species are recognized presently in the genus (Cigliano et al. 2021):
A. amboinensis ( Karsch, 1886 )
,
A . annulicornis Chopard, 1936
,
A. aureopubescens Wiendl, 1970
,
A . bicolor Chopard, 1928
,
A . brevipalpis Chopard, 1969
,
A . istrapura Gorochov, 2003
,
A . jacobsoni Chopard, 1924
,
A . lepidus Chopard, 1969
,
A . maindroni ( Chopard, 1969 )
,
A . microphtalmus Chopard, 1929
,
A. nietneri ( Saussure, 1878 )
.

Two subgenera have been defined by Gorochov (1996) , i.e., subgenus
Euarachnomimus Gorochov, 1996
(for
amboinensis
) and subgenus
Arachnomimus Saussure, 1897
(for the other 10 species). Here, according to unique characters of male genitalia, we define the subgenus
Arachnomimus
Indimimus Desutter-Grandcolas
& Jaiswara ,
subgen. nov.
, for
A. jayanti
Jaiswara
sp. nov.
( type species) and
A. annulicornis Chopard, 1936
. Species known by females only (
aureopubescens
,
brevipalpis , maindroni
, micropthalmus ) or which male genitalia have not been described yet (
jacobsoni
), should be classified incertae sedis within the genus
Arachnomimus
.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 1. Distribution map of
Arachnomimus species
in Indian subcontinent and Southeast Asia.
Arachnomimus (Arachnomimus) aureopubescens Wiendl, 1970
with its type locality in Lençóis Paulista, São Paulo, Brazil is not shown here.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Distribution. Apart from one species described from Brazil (
A. aureopubescens
, which female syntypes have not been re-examined since its description),
Arachnomimus
is distributed from Indian subcontinent to Indonesia in the Southeast Asia ( Fig. 1 ). Five species are from Sri Lanka (
annulicornis
,
bicolor
,
brevipalpis
,
istrapura
,
nietneri
), two from Malaysia (
jacobsoni
,
microphtalmus
) and one from Ambon , Indonesia (
amboinensis
). Three species are distributed in India , i.e.,
lepidus
and
maindroni
in Tamil Nadu (South India ), and
jayanti
Jaiswara
sp. nov.
in Chhattisgarh (Central India ).

Arachnomimus Euarachnomimus
is known from Ambon island,
Arachnomimus Arachnomimus
is known from India , Sri Lanka and Malaysia and
Arachnomimus
Indimimus Desutter-Grandcolas
& Jaiswara ,
subgen. nov.
is known only from India .

Habitat. Known from caves ( Karsch, 1886 ).
Arachnomimus
has not been observed at night outside caves, but it seems to colonize mainly cave twilight zone.

heading.emphasis:
Key to subgenera of
Arachnomimus Saussure, 1897

subSubSection.paragraph:
Male genitalia: Pseudepiphallic parameres independent from pseudepiphallic ‘arms’ ( Fig. 2B )...............................................................................
Indimimus Desutter-Grandcolas
& Jaiswara ,
subgen. nov.

2. Male genitalia compact, wider than long.................................. subgen.
Euarachnomimus Gorochov, 1996

Male genitalia less compact, longer than wide................................ subgen.
Arachnomimus Saussure, 1897

heading.emphasis:
Key to the Indian species of
Arachnomimus Saussure, 1897

subSubSection.paragraph:
1. Size smaller (FIII < 15 mm ). Face and cheeks black, shining. Pro, meso, metanotum and first two abdominal tergites blackish with yellow posterior margins........................................................
A. lepidus Chopard, 1969

2. Head whitish above, occiput brown. DD whitish with a wide brown band along the anterior margin. Meso and metanotum rufous brown with whitish posterior margins. Tergites yellowish with about 10 brown spots disposed in a longitudinal line................................................................................
A. maindroni Chopard, 1969

Head light brown. Pronotum with light brown pyriform inscriptions. Pro, meso and metanotum either of the color of body or with light brown patches dorsally. Posterior margin of mesonotum lined with very thin yellowish-brown band; posterior margin of metanotum with a wide, white band. Tergites of abdomen either completely dark brown or light brown ornamented with dark brown spots.....................................................................
A. jayanti
Jaiswara
sp. nov.

subSection.paragraph:
Other species included.
Arachnomimus annulicornis Chopard, 1936
(according to Chopard’s 1936 Fig. 13b).
Etymology. The subgeneric name is derived from combination of two words, India (country of origin) and mimus (usual name for these crickets).

Diagnosis.
Indimimus Desutter-Grandcolas
& Jaiswara ,
subgen. nov.
present the same morphological characters as the other two subgenera of
Arachnomimus
, from which it can be separated by the shape of pseudepiphallic sclerite and parameres of male genitalia: pseudepiphallic sclerite transverse, very narrow, plain (it is longer and subdivided into bifid sclerites separated from membranous median part in the other subgenera); distal margin with two shallow paired processes (variable in other two subgenera); lateral portions of pseudepiphallic sclerite largely extended distally as separate ‘arms’ (they are short and wide in the other two subgenera); parameres forming independent median hooks, not connected to the ‘arms’ (they are located on the inner side of each ‘arm’ in the other two subgenera, giving the genitalia a different bifid shape; in some specimens, all these structures are grouped together, giving the genitalia the shape of a compact broad triangle with short, disto-lateral structures). Additional characters (after
jayanti
Jaiswara, sp. nov. ): endophallic sclerite very long and thin, bearing a long crest-like apodeme; endophallic cavity lacking.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 2. Male genitalia of (A)
Arachnomimus nietneri ( Saussure, 1878 )
and (B)
A. annulicornis Chopard, 1936
. Images adapted from Chopard’s (1936) Fig. 13. Structures highlighted in pink represent pseudepiphallic sclerite and in green pseudepiphallic paramere.

subSection.paragraph:
According to genitalic characters,
Arachnomimus
and
Euarachnomimus
seem more closely related to one another than from
Indimimus Desutter-Grandcolas
& Jaiswara ,
subgen. nov.
Both
Indimimus Desutter-Grandcolas
& Jaiswara ,
subgen. nov.
and
Euarachnomimus
have four outer and three inner subapical spurs on hind tibiae, while most
Arachnomimus species
have four inner and four outer subapical spurs.

Remark. Chopard (1936 , Fig. 13b) illustrated the pseudepiphallic structures of
A. annulicornis
, and compared it with
A. nietneri
(his Fig. 13a), the type species of the genus: the figures clearly illustrate the presence of two different types of pseudepiphallic sclerites in the genus. It must be noted that the figures were not oriented in the same way in Chopard’s original paper, the figure 13a (
nietneri
) being oriented with the distal part of genitalia up (hence the ectophallic apodemes shown downwards), while the figure 13b is oriented downwards (see Fig. 2 , adapted from Chopard’s (1936) Fig. 13).

Pseudepiphallic sclerite of
A. annulicornis
is similar to
A. Indimimus
jayanti Jaiswara,
sp. nov.

Type locality.
India , Chhattisgarh , Raigarh district, Lailunga Block, Kurra, Kurra cave. GPS Coordinates: 22° 25’ 52.4928’’ N , 83° 27’ 21.618’’ E .

Type material. Holotype :
1 male , 14. vi. 2019 , India , Chhattisgarh , Raigarh district, Lailunga Block, Kurra, Kurra cave, ZSI. Temperature- 27.2°C, Humidity- 85%, Time- 1400hr.
Allotype :
1 female , locality same as holotype , ZSI.
Paratypes :
6 males 14. vi. 2019 (PU-RJINS142−147) and 9 females 14. vi. 2019 (PU-RJINS148−156), locality same as holotype .

caption.paragraph: FIGURE 3. Outside view of Kurra cave, Chhattisgarh, India from outside: encircled area is to show the large entrance (a) and arrows in red indicate multiple smaller entrances (b). Photo credit: Ranjit Singh.

FIGURE 4. Adult (a) and subadult (b) male of
Arachnomimus (Indimimus) jayanti
Jaiswara
sp. nov.
showing general body coloration with distinct white band on outer margin of metanotum and antennae. Photo credit: Ranjit Singh.

FIGURE 5.
Arachnomimus (Indimimus) jayanti
Jaiswara, sp. nov. Adult male in dorsal (A) and lateral view (B); Adult female in dorsal (C) and lateral view (D); Subadult male in dorsal (E) and lateral view (F). Scale 8mm.

subSection.paragraph: Additional material. Juveniles, 2 males (PU-RJINS142−147), 27. i. 2021 , India , Chhattisgarh , Raigarh district, Lailunga Block, Kurra, Kurra cave. Temperature- 23.4°C, Time- 1500hr.

Etymology. The specific epithet “
jayanti
” is derived from the first name of Dr. Jayant Biswas, (Founder, President cum Director of National Cave Research and Protection Organization, India ) in recognition of his significant studies on biology of cave animals in India .

Diagnosis.
Indimimus jayanti
Jaiswara
sp. nov.
differs from others in coloration − head dorsum and face light to dark brown, mesonotum posterior margin lined with very thin yellowish-brown band, metanotum posterior margin bearing distinct white band ( Fig. 4−6 ) and male genitalia (pseudepiphallic 'arms' and parameres largely separated; see Fig. 7 ).

Description : In addition to the characters of the genus: Large species with very long legs but short body ( Fig. 4 & 5 ). Body covered with dense, short setae. Head. Head slightly longer than wide in front view ( Fig. 6A ). Occiput covered with strong brown setae. Eyes small, distinctly protruding ( Fig. 6B, E ). Fastigium slightly wider than the scape. Ocelli small, located in triangle, round in shape; median ocellus apical; distance from median to lateral ocellus twice as that of between lateral ocelli. Scape longer than wide. Maxillary palpi very long and extremely thin; articles 3 and 4 subequal in length; article 5 longer than articles 3 and 4, strongly widened distally, distal margin strongly slanting, dorsal margin concave ( Fig. 6D ). Pronotum . Transverse; dorsal disc flat, medially divided by longitudinal shallow line; anterior margin slightly concave, posterior margin straight ( Fig. 6B ); postero-lateral lobes raised dorsally ( Fig. 6C ), pronotum antero-laterally in dorsal view slightly bulging ( Fig. 6B & E ); anterior and lateral margins of pronotum less densely lined with setae than the posterior margin. Mesonotum very short compared to pro and metanotum. Metanotum as wide as, or slightly wider than, pronotum ( Fig. 6E ). Legs. All long and very thin. TI without tympanum; a pair of long and thin apical spurs, both of the same length or inner occasionally slightly longer. TII with a pair of long and thin apical spurs, outer longer. FI and FII thinner on mid-length. FIII proximal half almost four times wider than distal half, distal half filiform, its width similar to the width of FI and FII. TIII with three pairs of apical spurs, outer spurs shorter; median spur the longest on both inner and outer sides; with 3 inner and 4 outer subapical spurs; serrulated on both inner and outer margins, except between apical and subapical spurs; spines most often thick and bent over the tibia; subapical spurs alternately arranged on inner and outer margins, outer subapical spurs longer than inners, apical end of both inner and outer subapical spurs inwardly bent ( Table 2 & 3 ). Abdomen. First tergite almost as wide as metanotum and almost of same color. Cerci very long, almost of the length of body ( Fig. 5 A-D) in adults and more than twice the body length ( Fig. 5 E-F) in subadults.

Coloration. Dark brown interspersed with light brown patches dorsally. Head distinctly light brown; cheek light to dark brown, occasionally blackish, face brown to black, frons occasionally light brown ( Fig. 6 A-C). Eyes dark brown to black. Clypeus and labrum light brown. Mandibles proximal region mostly light brown and distal, dark brown. Maxillary and labial palps light brown; 5th article of maxillary palpi dark brown distally. Scape light brown; antennae brown with a wide, white band of 4-5mm ( Fig. 5 A-F). Pro, meso and metanotum either of the color of body or with light brown patches dorsally; pronotum with light brown pyriform inscriptions ( Fig. 6B ). Posterior margin of mesonotum lined with very thin yellowish-brown band, posterior margin of metanotum with a white band ( Fig. 4 & 5 ; 6B, C & E ). Pronotum margin lined with thick dark brown setae. Tergites of abdomen either completely dark brown or light brown ornamented with dark brown spots; sternites light brown to off-white. Femora and cerci light brown; tibiae dark brown mottled with light brown patches.

Male genitalia ( Fig. 7 A-C)
. Pseudepiphallus in dorsal view transverse and very narrow, anterior margin not emarginated, corners slightly upwardly curled; posterior margin with two shallow paired processes; pseudepiphallic sclerite with a pair of long lateral sclerites (‘arms’) bearing at one third of their inner margin a shallow projection. Pseudepiphallic parameres broad, J-shaped (in top-view) with separate dorsal and ventral part; dorsal part short and thick as thick as a hook; ventral part much longer almost of the length of pseudepiphallic arms, narrowing distally, curved towards dorsal side. Rami thick, curved and long (almost of the length of pseudepiphallus arms), posteriorly deeply bifurcated and connected to pseudepiphallic sclerite.

Ectophallic apodemes short and thick, slightly diverging from the arc. Ectophallic fold membranous, slightly beyond the anterior margin of pseudepiphallus. Endophallic sclerite long and thin; no dorsal cavity.
Female . Apterous. Distal margin of subgenital plate only slightly sinuated. Ovipositor shorter than FIII in length (See Table 1 ); valves apex hardly widened and without ornamentation.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 6. External morphological features of
Arachnomimus (Indimimus) jayanti
Jaiswara,
sp. nov.
showing face (A), headpronotum in dorsal (B) and lateral view (C), maxillary palpi (D), band on outer margin of meso and metanotum (E), female subgenital plate (G), female supranal plate (H), male subgenital plate in dorsal (I) and lateral view (J). Scale 2mm.

FIGURE 7. Male genitalia of
Arachnomimus (Indimimus) jayanti
Jaiswara,
sp. nov.
in dorsal (A), ventral (B) and side (C) views. Abbreviations, see Material and methods section. Scale 1mm.

subSection.paragraph: Female genitalia . Copulatory papilla longer than wide, broadly rectangular with triangular and truncated apex; well sclerotized; with a plicated membranous “sleeve” at base, as in Fig. 8 A-C.

Subadult. Subadults differing from male only in coloration. Overall body coloration-pale brown, head, pro, meso and metanotum and legs ornamented with distinctly dark brown patches. White band on the posterior margin of metanotum and antennae distinctly visible in subadults also. Abdomen dark brown ( Fig. 5E & F ).

Habitat.
Indimimus jayanti
Jaiswara,
sp. nov.
is currently known only from Kurra cave, Chhattisgarh , India . The cave has a very large entrance, allowing great amount of light illuminating the twilight zone. The large entrance is supplemented with multiple smaller entrances ( Fig. 3 ). Individuals of this species were mostly found in the twilight zone and a few in the transition zone of the cave. Inner most region of the cave was packed with millions of insectivorous bats and the floor was covered with thick bed of guano. Both adults and subadults (especially) of this cricket species camouflaged well with the walls of the cave ( Fig. 4 ). Given they were only found in the twilight and transition zone, they may be going out of the cave for night time foraging and may be using the cave for day roosting.
